('Lily and Tom liked to collect things. They had a big box full of shells, rocks, feathers, and stickers. One day, they found a map in a book. It had a picture of a treasure chest and a red X."Let\'s follow the map and find the treasure!" Lily said."OK, but we need to be clever. The map has clues and riddles," Tom said.They took the map and went outside. They looked at the first clue. It said: "Go to the place where you swing and slide." They knew it was the playground. They ran there and looked for the next clue.The next clue said: "Look under the thing that has four legs and a tail." They thought hard. They saw a dog, a cat, a horse, and a bench. They decided it was the bench. They lifted it and found the third clue.The third clue said: "Count the flowers that are yellow and blue. Add them together and that\'s the number you need." They counted the flowers in the garden. There were six yellow ones and four blue ones. They added them and got ten.They looked at the map again. It showed a big tree with a hole. Next to the hole was a red X. They ran to the tree and looked inside. They saw a shiny treasure chest. They opened it and found lots of coins, jewels, and toys."Wow, we found the treasure!" Lily said."We are so clever!" Tom said.They hugged and cheered. They decided to share the treasure with their friends. They were very happy. They loved to collect things.', ' Past Tense:Lily and Tom had liked collecting things. They had possessed a large box filled with shells, rocks, feathers, and stickers. One day, they had discovered a map within a book. The map had depicted a treasure chest and a red X."Let\'s follow the map and find the treasure!" Lily had exclaimed."OK, but we must be clever. The map contained clues and riddles," Tom had advised.They had taken the map and ventured outside. They had examined the first clue. It had read: "Go to the place where you swing and slide." They had recognized it as the playground. They had sprinted there and searched for the subsequent clue.The next clue had stated: "Look under the thing that has four legs and a tail." They had pondered. They had seen a dog, a cat, a horse, and a bench. They had determined it was the bench. They had lifted it and unearthed the third clue.The third clue had declared: "Count the flowers that are yellow and blue. Add them together and that number you shall seek." They had enumerated the flowers in the garden. There had been six yellow ones and four blue ones. They had added them and arrived at ten.They had revisited the map. It had revealed a grand tree with a hollow. Near the hollow had been a red X. They had dashed to the tree and inspected the cavity. They had beheld a gleaming treasure chest. They had unlocked it and discovered an abundance of coins, jewels, and toys."Wow, we had found the treasure!" Lily had expressed."We had been so clever!" Tom had concurred.They had embraced and rejoiced. They had decided to share the treasure with their friends. They had been extremely content. They had cherished their collection of trinkets.', 1)
('Ben and Lily were playing with their toys in the living room. They liked to pretend that they were tiny and their toys were big. They used a frame from a picture to make a door for their toy house."Knock, knock," Ben said, tapping on the frame. "Can I come in?""Of course, you can," Lily said, opening the frame. "You are very polite. Do you want some tea?""Yes, please," Ben said, sitting on a cushion. Lily poured some water from a bottle cap into a thimble. They pretended to sip their tea and chat.Suddenly, they heard a loud noise. It was their mom, coming home from work. She saw the frame on the floor and picked it up."Oh, what a nice frame," she said. "I wonder where it came from. I think I\'ll hang it on the wall."She did not see Ben and Lily inside the frame. They were too small. They shouted and waved, but their mom did not hear them."Help, help!" Ben cried. "We are in the frame!""How did we shrink?" Lily asked. "We need to get out!"They looked around and saw a window in the frame. They ran to it and pushed it open. They saw a bird outside. They hoped it would not eat them."Maybe we can fly with the bird," Ben said. "Maybe it will take us to our mom."They climbed on the bird\'s back and held on tight. The bird flew away with them. They hoped it would not fly too far. They wanted to go back to their mom and their toys. They wanted to be big again.', ' Past Tense:Ben and Lily played with their toys in the living room. They pretended that they were tiny and their toys were big. They used a frame from a picture to make a door for their toy house.Knock, knock, Ben tapped on the frame and asked, "Can I come in?" Lily opened the frame and replied, "Of course, you can. You were very polite. Do you want some tea?" Ben sat on a cushion, and Lily poured water from a bottle cap into a thimble for them to sip.Suddenly, they heard a loud noise. It was their mom coming home from work. She picked up the frame from the floor and wondered where it came from, intending to hang it on the wall. She didn\'t see Ben and Lily inside the frame."Help, help!" Ben cried. "We were in the frame!" Lily asked, "How did we shrink?" They looked around and saw a window in the frame. They ran to it and pushed it open, climbing onto a bird outside. ('Tim and Jen are twins. They like to play with cars and trucks. They have many cars and trucks in their room. They make noises like vroom and beep.One day, mom says, "We are going to the park. Get ready." Tim and Jen are happy. They love the park. They want to bring their cars and trucks. They put some in a bag.Mom takes them to the car. She says, "I have a surprise for you. We have a new driver today. His name is Bob. He is very nice. Say hello to Bob."Tim and Jen look at Bob. He is sitting in the front. He has a big nose, a big beard, and a big hat. He smiles at them. He says, "Hello, Tim and Jen. I am Bob. I am your driver today. Are you ready to go to the park?"Tim and Jen think Bob is ugly. They do not like his nose, his beard, and his hat. They do not say hello. They hide behind mom. They whisper, "Mom, we do not like Bob. He is ugly. Can we have another driver?"Mom says, "Shh, Tim and Jen. That is not nice. Bob is not ugly. He is different. He is a good driver. He will take us to the park safely. You should be polite and friendly. Say hello to Bob."Tim and Jen feel bad. They do not want to be rude. They peek at Bob. He still smiles at them. He says, "Do you like cars and trucks? I see you have some in your bag. I like cars and trucks too. I have some in my hat. Do you want to see?"Tim and Jen are curious. They like cars and trucks. They nod. Bob takes off his hat. He shows them his cars and trucks. They are small and colorful. He says, "These are my cars and trucks. I bring them with me everywhere. They are my friends. Do you want to play with them?"Tim and Jen are surprised. They think Bob is funny. They like his cars and trucks. They say, "Yes, please. Can we play with them?" They take some from his hat. They make noises like vroom and beep.Bob says, "Sure, you can play with them. But be careful. Do not lose them. They are very special to me." He puts his hat back on. He says, "Now, let\'s go to the park. Are you ready?"Tim and Jen say, "Yes, we are ready. Thank you, Bob. You are a nice driver. And you are not ugly. You are different. And we like different." They smile at Bob. They hold their cars and trucks. They are happy.Mom says, "That\'s good, Tim and Jen. I am proud of you. You are learning to be kind and respectful. And you are making a new friend. Bob is a good driver. And he is a good person. And he has a good hat." She smiles at Bob. She says, "Thank you, Bob. You are a great driver. And you have a great hat." She buckles up. She says, "Now, let\'s go to the park. And have some fun."', ' Past Tense:Tim and Jen were twins. They had enjoyed playing with cars and trucks in their room, filled with numerous toys. They made noises of "vroom" and "beep." One day, mom announced, "We are going to the park. Get ready." Tim and Jen had been excited. They adored the park. They wanted to bring their cars and trucks. They selected some and put them in a bag.Mom drove them to the car. She shared, "I have a surprise for you. We have a new driver today. His name was Bob. He was very nice." Tim and Jen had looked at Bob, who sat in the front seat. He had a big nose, a big beard, and a big hat. He smiled at them. He greeted, "Hello, Tim and Jen. I am Bob. I am your driver today. Are you ready to go to the park?"Tim and Jen had found Bob unattractive. They had not returned his greeting. They hid behind mom. They whispered, "Mom, we don\'t like Bob. He\'s ugly. Can we have another driver?"Mom had hushed them, "Shh, Tim and Jen. That\'s not nice. Bob is not ugly. He is different. He is a good driver. He will take us to the park safely. You should be polite and friendly. Say hello to Bob."Tim and Jen had felt guilty. They didn\'t want to be rude. They peeked at Bob. He still smiled at them. He said, "Do you like cars and trucks? I see you have some in your bag. I like cars and trucks too. I have some in my hat. Do you want to see?"Tim and Jen had been intrigued. They loved cars and trucks. They nodded. Bob removed his hat, revealing his collection. They were small and colorful. He said, "These are my cars and trucks. I bring them with me everywhere. They are my friends. Do you want to play with them?"Tim and Jen had been surprised. They thought Bob was amusing. They liked his cars and trucks. They said, "Yes, please. Can we play with them?" They took some from his hat. They made noises of "vroom" and "beep."Bob had agreed, "Sure, you can play with them. But be careful. Don\'t lose them. They are very special to me." He put his hat back on. He said, "Now, let\'s go to the park. Are you ready?"Tim and Jen had replied, "Yes, we are ready. Thank you, Bob. You are a nice driver. And you\'re not ugly. You\'re different. And we like different." They smiled at Bob. They held their cars and trucks. They were happy.Mom had commented, "That\'s good, Tim and Jen. I\'m proud of you. You\'re learning to be kind and respectful. And you\'re making a new friend. Bob is a good driver. And he\'s a good person. And he has a good hat." She smiled at Bob. She said, "Thank you, Bob. You\'re a great driver. And you have a great hat." She buckled up. She said, "Now, let\'s go to the park.', 1)
('Tom and Mia were friends who liked to play outside. One day, they saw a big tree with many branches. Tom wanted to climb the tree and see how high he could go. He said to Mia, "Let\'s climb the tree! It will be fun!"Mia was fearful of the tree. She thought it was too tall and dangerous. She said to Tom, "No, I don\'t want to climb the tree. I\'m scared. What if we fall?"Tom said, "Don\'t be scared. I will help you. Climbing the tree will make us strong and brave. We will have power over the tree."Mia was not sure, but she wanted to be strong and brave too. She agreed to climb the tree with Tom. They held hands and started to climb. They climbed slowly and carefully, looking for places to put their feet and hands.They climbed higher and higher, until they reached a big branch. They sat on the branch and looked around. They saw the sky, the birds, the flowers, and the other trees. They felt happy and proud. They had climbed the tree!They smiled at each other and said, "We did it! We climbed the tree! We are strong and brave! We have power over the tree!"They hugged and decided to climb down. They climbed down slowly and carefully, until they reached the ground. They ran to their parents and told them what they had done. Their parents were happy and proud too. They praised Tom and Mia for their courage and skill.Tom and Mia felt good. They had overcome their fear and had a new adventure. They had learned something new and had fun. They had climbed the tree!', ' Past Tense:Tom and Mia were friends who enjoyed playing outside. One day, they came across a large tree with numerous branches. Tom expressed his desire to climb the tree and discover how high he could ascend. He turned to Mia and suggested, "Let\'s climb this tree! It will be enjoyable!"Mia, however, harbored a fear of the tree, deeming it too tall and perilous. She voiced her concerns to Tom, "I don\'t want to climb the tree. I\'m scared. What if we fall?"Tom attempted to alleviate her fears, assuring her that he would assist her. He encouraged, "Don\'t be afraid. Climbing the tree will make us strong and courageous. We will have control over the tree."Mia hesitated but yearned for strength and bravery. She agreed to climb the tree with Tom. They intertwined their hands and initiated their ascent. They progressed gradually and cautiously, seeking secure footing and handholds.They advanced higher and higher, eventually reaching a substantial branch. They settled on the branch and surveyed their surroundings. They beheld the sky, the birds, the flowers, and the other trees. They felt elated and accomplished. They had conquered the tree.They exchanged smiles and declared, "We did it! We climbed the tree! We are strong and brave! We have power over the tree!"They embraced and decided to descend. They descended slowly and carefully, eventually returning to the ground. They rushed to their parents and shared their achievement. Their parents were pleased and proud. They commended Tom and Mia for their courage and dexterity.Tom and Mia felt content. They had vanquished their fear and embarked on a new adventure. They had acquired a new skill and experienced joy. They had scaled the tree.', 1)
('Ben and Lily went to the park with Mom. They saw a huge pond with many ducks. Ben and Lily liked ducks. They wanted to feed them."Mom, can we give them some bread?" Lily asked."Sorry, sweetie, we don\'t have any bread. But we have some olives. Do you think they will like olives?" Mom said."Let\'s try!" Ben said. He took an olive from Mom\'s bag and threw it into the pond. A duck saw the olive and swam to get it. It picked up the olive with its beak and ate it."Yay! The duck likes olives!" Ben cheered."Me too! Me too!" Lily said. She took another olive and threw it into the pond. Another duck swam to get it. It also ate the olive."Wow! The ducks love olives!" Lily said."Can we swim with the ducks, Mom?" Ben asked."No, honey, the pond is too deep and cold for you. And the ducks might not like it. They need their space. But you can watch them swim and quack. They are very happy." Mom said."Okay, Mom. We will watch them. They are very cute." Ben said."Yes, they are. And you are very kind to share your olives with them." Mom said.Ben and Lily smiled. They sat on the grass and watched the ducks swim and eat olives. They had a lot of fun at the park.', ' Past Tense:Ben and Lily went to the park with Mom. We saw a huge pond filled with many ducks. Ben and Lily enjoyed ducks. They wished to feed them."Mom, could we give them some bread?" Lily had asked."Sorry, sweetie, we didn\'t have any bread. But we had some olives. Do you think they would like olives?" Mom suggested."Let\'s try!" Ben exclaimed. He took an olive from Mom\'s bag and threw it into the pond. A duck spotted the olive and swam towards it. The duck picked up the olive with its beak and consumed it."Yay! The duck liked olives!" Ben cheered."Me too! Me too!" Lily echoed. She threw another olive into the pond. Another duck approached and ate it."Wow! The ducks loved olives!" Lily marveled."Could we swim with the ducks, Mom?" Ben inquired."No, honey, the pond was too deep and cold for you. And the ducks might not appreciate it. They required their space," Mom explained."Okay, Mom. We will observe them. They were very cute," Ben agreed."Yes, they were. And you were very kind to share your olives with them," Mom praised.Ben and Lily smiled. We sat on the grass and watched the ducks swim and quack. We had an enjoyable time at the park.', 1)
('Tim and Sam are playing with blocks. They like to build towers and houses and cars. Tim has a red block and Sam has a blue block. They want to make a big tower."Let me add my block to your block," Tim says. He puts his red block on top of Sam\'s blue block."No, I don\'t like that," Sam says. He pushes Tim\'s block away. "I want to add my block to your block."They both try to add their blocks to each other\'s blocks. They start to fight. They pull and push and shout."Stop it, stop it!" Mom says. She comes to see what is wrong. She sees the blocks on the floor. She sees Tim and Sam crying."What are you doing?" Mom asks. "Why are you fighting?""We want to add our blocks," Tim says."But we don\'t like the same colors," Sam says.Mom picks up a yellow block. She shows it to Tim and Sam."Look, this is a useful block," Mom says. "It can make your tower more colorful. It can also make a flame for your car. Do you want to try?"Tim and Sam nod. They wipe their tears. They take the yellow block from Mom. They take turns to add it to their blocks. They make a tall tower with a red, blue and yellow block. They make a car with a yellow flame. They smile and hug."Thank you, Mom," Tim and Sam say. "You are useful too."', ' Past Tense:Tim and Sam played with blocks. They enjoyed building towers, houses, and cars. Tim had a red block, while Sam had a blue one. They aimed to create a big tower."I\'ll add my block to yours," Tim suggested. He placed his red block atop Sam\'s blue one."I don\'t like that," Sam objected. He pushed Tim\'s block away. "I want to add my block to yours."They both tried to add their blocks to each other\'s. A fight ensued. They pulled, pushed, and shouted."Stop it, stop it!" Mom exclaimed. She arrived to investigate. She saw the blocks on the floor and Tim and Sam crying."What\'s going on?" Mom inquired. "Why are you fighting?""We wanted to add our blocks," Tim explained."But we don\'t like the same colors," Sam added.Mom picked up a yellow block. She presented it to Tim and Sam. "This block is useful," she said. "It can make your tower more colorful. It can also make a flame for your car. Would you like to try?"Tim and Sam nodded. They wiped their tears. They took the yellow block from Mom. They took turns adding it to their blocks. They constructed a tall tower with a red, blue, and yellow block. They made a car with a yellow flame. They smiled and hugged."Thank you, Mom," Tim and Sam expressed their gratitude. "You\'re useful too."', 1)
('Anna and Ben are playing with their baby brother, Sam. Sam is very small and cute, but he is also very persistent. He wants to grab everything he sees, even if it is not his."Look, Sam, this is a ball. You can roll it and bounce it," Anna says, showing him a red ball. She rolls it to him gently, and he smiles and tries to catch it."No, Sam, this is a book. You can read it and learn new words," Ben says, holding a colorful book. He opens it and points to a picture of a dog. "This is a dog. It says woof-woof."Sam reaches for the book, but Ben pulls it away. "No, Sam, this is mine. You have the ball."Sam frowns and starts to cry. He does not want the ball. He wants the book."Ben, don\'t be mean. Share with Sam. He is just curious," Anna says, taking the book from Ben. She gives it to Sam, who stops crying and laughs. He likes the book."Fine, I don\'t care. I have the ball," Ben says, rolling the ball away. He pretends he is not interested in the book.But Sam is persistent. He crawls after Ben, dragging the book with him. He wants to share the book with Ben. He thinks Ben will like it too."Sam, leave me alone. I don\'t want the book. I want the ball," Ben says, pushing Sam away.Sam does not give up. He keeps crawling and laughing. He thinks it is a game."Sam, stop it. You are annoying me," Ben says, getting angry.Anna watches them and laughs too. She thinks they are funny. She loves her baby brother and her big brother. She knows they love each other too, even if they fight sometimes. She decides to join them and play with the ball and the book. She thinks they will have more fun together.', ' Past Tense:Anna and Ben played with their baby brother, Sam, last evening. Sam was small and cute, but persistent. He wanted to grab everything he saw, even if it wasn\'t his."Look, Sam, this was a ball. You could roll it and bounce it," Anna had said, showing him a red ball. She rolled it gently to him, and he smiled and tried to catch it."No, Sam, this was a book. You could read it and learn new words," Ben had said, holding a colorful book. He opened it and pointed to a picture of a dog. "This was a dog. It says woof-woof."Sam reached for the book, but Ben pulled it away. "No, Sam, this was mine. You had the ball."Sam frowned and started to cry. He didn\'t want the ball. He wanted the book."Ben, don\'t be mean. Share with Sam. He is just curious," Anna had said, taking the book from Ben. She gave it to Sam, who stopped crying and laughed. He liked the book."Fine, I don\'t care. I have the ball," Ben had said, rolling the ball away. He pretended he was not interested in the book.But Sam was persistent. He crawled after Ben, dragging the book with him. He wanted to share the book with Ben. He thought Ben would like it too."Sam, leave me alone. I didn\'t want the book. I wanted the ball," Ben had said, pushing Sam away.Sam did not give up. He kept crawling and laughing. He thought it was a game."Sam, stop it. You were annoying me," Ben had said, getting angry.Anna watched them and laughed too. She thought they were funny. She loved her baby brother and her big brother. She knew they loved each other too, even if they fought sometimes. She decided to join them and play with the ball and the book. She thought they would have more fun together.', 1)
('Lily liked to splash in the water. She had a big tub in her room with many toys. She liked to make waves and bubbles and sing songs. Sometimes her mom or dad would join her and splash with her.One day, Lily had to go to the office with her mom. Her mom had to work on her computer and talk to people. Lily had to be patient and quiet. She brought some books and crayons, but she soon got bored. She wanted to splash in the water.She saw a big bottle of water on a table. It looked like fun. She went to the table and tried to open the bottle. But it was too hard. She pushed and pulled and twisted, but nothing happened. She got angry and kicked the bottle.The bottle fell off the table and broke on the floor. Water splashed everywhere. Lily was surprised and scared. She heard her mom shout, "Lily, what did you do?"Lily started to cry. She ran to her mom and hugged her. Her mom was wet and angry, but also worried. She said, "Lily, you can\'t splash water in the office. It\'s not safe. You could hurt yourself or others. You have to be patient and listen to me."Lily said, "I\'m sorry, mom. I wanted to splash in the water. I like to splash in the water. Can we go home and splash in the water?"Her mom sighed and said, "Maybe later, Lily. But first we have to clean up this mess. And then we have to say sorry to the people in the office. Can you do that?"Lily nodded and said, "Yes, mom. I can do that. I love you, mom."Her mom smiled and said, "I love you too, Lily. But next time, please don\'t splash water in the office."', ' Past Tense:Lily enjoyed splashing in the water. She had a large tub in her room filled with numerous toys. She used to make waves and bubbles, singing songs as she played. Occasionally, her mom or dad would join her, and they would splash together.One day, Lily accompanied her mom to the office. Her mom needed to work on her computer and engage in conversations. Lily had to remain patient and quiet. She brought books and crayons, but soon grew bored. She yearned to splash in the water.She noticed a large bottle of water on a table. It seemed entertaining. She approached the table and attempted to open the bottle. However, it was too difficult. She pulled and twisted, but it remained closed. Frustrated, she kicked the bottle.The bottle toppled off the table and shattered on the floor. Water spilled everywhere. Lily was taken aback and frightened. She heard her mom exclaim, "Lily, what did you do?"Lily began to cry. She rushed to her mom and embraced her. Her mom was wet and irate, yet also concerned. She stated, "Lily, you couldn\'t splash water in the office. It\'s not safe. You could injure yourself or others. You had to be patient and listen to me."Lily apologized, "I\'m sorry, mom. I wanted to splash in the water. I loved splashing in the water. Can we go home and splash in the water instead?"Her mom sighed and replied, "Perhaps later, Lily. But first, we need to clean up this mess. And then, we must apologize to the people in the office. Can you do that?"Lily nodded and agreed, "Yes, mom. I can do that. I love you, mom."Her mom smiled and said, "I love you too, Lily. But next time, please don\'t splash water in the office."', 1)
('Sara and Ben are friends. They like to play in the park. One day, they see a big dog. The dog is not nice. It barks and runs at them. Sara and Ben are scared."Help!" Sara cries. "The dog is bad!""Run!" Ben says. "We need to hide!"They run to a big tree. They climb up the tree. The dog cannot climb. It stays under the tree. It barks and jumps. Sara and Ben hug each other. They are not happy."Will the dog go away?" Sara asks."I don\'t know," Ben says. "But we are fine. We are together. We are unite.""What is unite?" Sara asks."Unite means we are one. We are strong. We are friends," Ben says.Sara smiles. She likes Ben. She likes unite. She says, "Yes, we are unite. We are friends. We are fine."They wait for the dog to leave. They hope someone will come and help them. They stay in the tree. They are unite. They are fine.', ' Past Tense:Sara and Ben were friends. They used to play in the park. One day, they saw a big dog. The dog was not nice. It barked and ran towards them. Sara cried out, "Help! The dog is bad!" Ben urged, "Run! We need to hide!" They ran to a big tree. They climbed up the tree. The dog couldn\'t climb. It stayed under the tree, barking and jumping. Sara and Ben hugged each other. They were not happy."Did the dog go away?" Sara asked."I don\'t know," Ben replied. "But we were fine. We were together.""What do you mean, \'unite\'?" Sara inquired."Unite means we were one. We were strong. We were friends," Ben explained.Sara smiled. She liked Ben. She liked the idea of being unite. "Yes, we were unite. We were friends. We were fine," she affirmed.They waited for the dog to leave. They hoped someone would come and help them. They stayed in the tree, united and safe.', 1)
('Lily and Ben were friends who liked to play in the garden. They liked to look at the flowers that had many colors and smells. They liked to touch the soft petals and the green leaves. They liked to pretend they were bees and butterflies.One day, they saw a new flower that they had never seen before. It was big and white and had a long stem. It looked like a bell. Lily and Ben wanted to see it closer. They ran to the flower and bent down to smell it."Wow, it smells so sweet!" Lily said. "I wonder what it is.""Maybe it is a magic flower," Ben said. "Maybe it can make wishes come true."They both closed their eyes and made a wish. Lily wished for a new doll. Ben wished for a new bike. They opened their eyes and waited for their wishes to come true.But nothing happened. The flower did not change. It did not give them anything. It only made a loud noise. It was not a flower at all. It was a trap. It was a snake that looked like a flower. It had been waiting for someone to come close. It had been waiting to bite.The snake bit Lily and Ben on their arms. It hurt a lot. They screamed and cried. They tried to run away, but they were too slow. The snake bit them again and again. It had poison in its teeth. The poison made them feel sick and sleepy. They fell to the ground and did not get up.The garden became gloomy. The sun hid behind the clouds. The wind blew the petals away. The other flowers did not bloom. They closed their buds and waited for the night. They were sad and scared. They had lost their friends. They had been fooled by the snake. They wished they had never seen the white flower. They wished they had never made a wish.', ' Past Tense:Lily and Ben had been friends who enjoyed playing in the garden. They had delighted in the flowers with their various colors and scents. They had taken pleasure in touching the soft petals and the green leaves. They had amused themselves by pretending they were bees and butterflies.One day, they had come across a new flower they had never seen before. It had been large and white with a long stem, resembling a bell. Intrigued, they had approached the flower to investigate."Wow, it smelled so sweet!" Lily had exclaimed. "What do you think it is?""Maybe it\'s a magic flower," Ben had suggested. "Maybe it can make wishes come true."They had both closed their eyes and made their wishes. Lily had wished for a new doll, and Ben had wished for a new bike. They had opened their eyes, waiting for their wishes to manifest.But nothing had happened. The flower had not changed, nor had it granted them anything. Instead, it had made a loud noise, revealing itself to be a snake cleverly disguised as a flower. It had been lying in wait for unsuspecting victims.The snake had bitten Lily and Ben on their arms, causing them great pain. They had screamed and cried out in terror. Despite their efforts to flee, they had been too slow, and the snake had continued to bite them again and again, its venomous teeth leaving them feeling sick and drowsy. Eventually, they had collapsed to the ground, unconscious.The garden had grown gloomy as the sun hid behind the clouds. The wind had blown the petals away, and the other flowers had closed their buds, waiting for the night. They had been saddened and frightened by the loss of their friends and the deception they had suffered at the hands of the snake. They had wished they had never seen the white flower and had never made a wish.', 1)
('Lila and Max were best friends. They liked to play together at the park. One day, they saw a big tree with green balls on it. They wondered what they were."Let\'s pick one and see," Max said. He climbed the tree and grabbed a green ball. He threw it to Lila. She caught it and looked at it. It was hard and bumpy."What is this?" Lila asked."I don\'t know. Maybe it\'s a toy," Max said.They tried to roll it, bounce it, and kick it. But it was not fun. It was too heavy and dull."Maybe we can open it," Lila said. She found a rock and hit the green ball with it. It cracked and showed a soft green inside and a big brown seed."Wow, look at that!" Max said. He climbed down and joined Lila. They touched the green inside. It was creamy and smooth."Can we eat it?" Lila asked."I don\'t know. Maybe we should ask someone," Max said.They saw a lady walking by with a dog. They ran to her and showed her the green ball."Excuse me, miss. What is this?" Max asked.The lady smiled and said, "That\'s an avocado. It\'s a fruit. You can eat it. It\'s very good for you. And very popular too. Many people like it.""Really? Can we try it?" Lila asked."Sure, why not. But you have to share it. And don\'t eat the seed. It\'s too hard," the lady said.She gave them a spoon and helped them scoop out the green inside. They tasted it. It was mild and buttery."Mmm, this is yummy," Lila said."I like it too," Max said.They ate the avocado and thanked the lady. They felt happy and full.They decided to keep the seed and plant it in the park. Maybe they could grow more avocados and share them with their friends.They settled on a spot near the tree and dug a hole. They put the seed in the hole and covered it with dirt. They watered it with their water bottles."Maybe one day, we\'ll have our own avocado tree," Lila said."That would be awesome," Max said.They hugged and smiled. They were best friends. And they loved avocados.', ' Past Tense:Lila and Max were the best of friends. They used to play together at the park. One day, they came across a large tree bearing green balls. They pondered over what these were.Max suggested, "Let\'s pick one and see." He ascended the tree and plucked a green ball. He tossed it to Lila, who caught it. She examined it, finding it hard and bumpy."What is this?" Lila inquired."I\'m not sure. Maybe it\'s a toy," Max replied.They attempted to roll, bounce, and kick the object, but it was unenjoyable. It was too heavy and uninteresting."Maybe we can open it," Lila suggested. She located a rock and struck the green ball with it. It cracked, revealing a soft green interior and a large brown seed."Wow, look at that!" Max exclaimed, descending from the tree to join Lila. They touched the green interior. It was creamy and smooth."Can we eat it?" Lila questioned."I\'m not sure. Maybe we should ask someone," Max advised.They spotted a lady walking by with a dog. They approached her and displayed the green ball."Excuse me, ma\'am. What is this?" Max inquired.The lady smiled and replied, "That\'s an avocado. It\'s a fruit. You can eat it. It\'s very good for you and quite popular. Many people enjoy it.""Really? Can we try it?" Lila asked.The lady granted them permission, but warned them to share it and avoid consuming the seed. She provided them with a spoon and assisted them in scooping out the green interior. They savored the mild and buttery taste."Mmm, this is delicious," Lila remarked."I agree," Max concurred.They thanked the lady and felt content. They decided to keep the seed and plant it in the park. Perhaps they could cultivate more avocados and share them with their friends.They selected a spot near the tree and excavated a hole. They placed the seed in the hole and covered it with soil. They watered it with their water bottles."Maybe someday, we\'ll have our own avocado tree," Lila mused."That would be amazing," Max agreed.They embraced and smiled. They were inseparable friends. And they cherished avocados.', 1)
('Ben and Mia were playing in the park with their dog, Spot. They liked to run and jump and slide and swing. Spot liked to chase and bark and fetch and roll. They were having a lot of fun.But then, they saw a big hole in the fence. They were curious. They wanted to see what was on the other side. They told Spot to stay and they crawled through the hole. They found a big field with flowers and trees and birds. They felt happy.They did not see the sign that said "Beware of the Bull". They did not hear the loud moo that came from behind the bushes. They did not notice the big, angry animal that was running towards them. They were in danger.Spot saw the bull. He was anxious. He wanted to rescue his friends. He barked and ran through the hole. He got to the field and saw the bull. He was brave. He jumped and bit the bull\'s tail. The bull was surprised. He stopped and turned around. He saw Spot and was scared. He ran away.Ben and Mia heard Spot\'s bark. They saw the bull and Spot. They were shocked. They realized they were in trouble. They ran back to the hole. They crawled through and hugged Spot. They thanked him for saving them. They learned their lesson. They decided to never go through the hole again. They went back to the park and played some more. They were safe.', ' Past Tense:Ben and Mia played in the park with their dog, Spot. We ran and jumped and slid and swung. Spot chased and barked and fetched and rolled. We had a lot of fun.But then, we saw a big hole in the fence. We were curious. We wanted to see what was on the other side. We told Spot to stay and we crawled through the hole. We discovered a big field with flowers and trees and birds. We felt happy.We didn\'t see the sign that said "Beware of the Bull." We didn\'t hear the loud moo that came from behind the bushes. We didn\'t notice the big, angry animal that was running towards us. We were in danger.Spot saw the bull. He was anxious. He wanted to rescue his friends. He barked and ran through the hole. He reached the field and saw the bull. He was brave. He jumped and bit the bull\'s tail. The bull was surprised. He stopped and turned around. He saw Spot and was scared. He ran away.We heard Spot\'s bark. We saw the bull and Spot. We were shocked. We realized we were in trouble. We ran back to the hole. We crawled through and hugged Spot. We thanked him for saving us. We learned our lesson. We decided to never go through the hole again. We went back to the park and played some more. We were safe.', 1)
('Anna and Ben are friends. They like to play outside. They enjoy exercise. They run, jump, and kick a ball. They are clever. They know how to share and take turns.One day, they see a big dog. The dog is black and white. It has a long tail. It looks friendly. Anna and Ben want to pet the dog. They run to the dog. They say, "Hello, dog! Can we play with you?"The dog does not like Anna and Ben. The dog is angry. It barks and growls. It shows its teeth. It bites Anna and Ben. They cry and scream. They are hurt. They are scared.A man comes. He is the dog\'s owner. He says, "Sorry, sorry! My dog is not nice. He does not like children. He is a guard dog. You should not go near him."Anna and Ben are sad and mad. They say, "You are a bad man! You should not have a bad dog! You should keep him away from us!"The man takes the dog and leaves. Anna and Ben go home. They tell their moms what happened. Their moms hug them and take them to the doctor. The doctor gives them medicine and bandages. He says, "You are brave. You will be okay. But you should be careful. Not all dogs are friendly. Some dogs are dangerous. You should always ask before you pet a dog."Anna and Ben learn a lesson. They do not enjoy exercise today. They do not feel clever. They feel sorry and silly. They wish they had not met the bad dog.', ' In the past, Anna and Ben were friends. They enjoyed playing outside together and exercising. They ran, jumped, and kicked a ball. Anna and Ben were clever and knew how to share and take turns. One day, they encountered a big dog. The dog was black and white with a long tail, and it appeared friendly. Anna and Ben approached the dog, saying, "Hello, dog! Can we play with you?" However, the dog did not like Anna and Ben. It became angry and barked, growled, and showed its teeth. The dog bit Anna and Ben, causing them to cry and scream in pain and fear. A man appeared, the dog\'s owner, and apologized, "Sorry, sorry! My dog is not nice. He doesn\'t like children. He is a guard dog. You should not have approached him." Anna and Ben were sad and angry. They accused the man, "You are a bad man! You should not have a bad dog! You should keep him away from us!" The man took the dog and left. Anna and Ben went home and told their mothers what had happened. Their mothers hugged them and took them to the doctor. The doctor gave them medicine and bandages and said, "You are brave. You will be okay. But you should be careful. Not all dogs are friendly. Some dogs are dangerous. You should always ask before you pet a dog." After this experience, Anna and Ben learned a valuable lesson. They did not enjoy exercising that day and felt sorry and silly for their encounter with the unfriendly dog.', 1)
('Anna and Ben were playing with their toys in the park. They saw a big crane lifting heavy things. They wanted to know how it worked."Let\'s go and ask the man who drives the crane," Ben said."OK, but be careful," Anna said.They ran to the crane and saw a man sitting inside. He was wearing a helmet and a vest."Hello, sir," Ben said. "Can you tell us how you make the crane move?"The man smiled and opened the door. He invited them to sit with him."Sure, I can tell you," he said. "The crane has a motor and a cable. The motor makes the cable go up and down. The cable has a hook at the end. I use a joystick to control the hook. I can lift and lower things with the hook.""Wow, that\'s amazing," Anna said. "You must be very intelligent to do that."The man laughed and said, "Thank you, but I\'m not the only one who is intelligent. The crane is also intelligent. It has sensors and computers that help me. They tell me how much weight I can lift and how far I can move. They also warn me if there is any danger or problem.""Really? How do they do that?" Ben asked.The man showed them a screen and some buttons. He explained how the sensors and computers worked. He also told them some rules and safety tips for using the crane.Anna and Ben learned a lot from the man. They thanked him and said goodbye. They went back to their toys and pretended to be crane drivers.They had fun and also learned something new. They realized that the crane was not just a big toy, but a useful and intelligent machine. They also realized that the man was not just a driver, but a teacher and a friend. They learned to be curious, respectful, and grateful.', ' Past Tense:Anna and Ben played with their toys in the park. They saw a big crane lifting heavy things. They were curious about how it worked."Let\'s go and ask the man who operates the crane," Ben suggested."Okay, but be careful," Anna warned.They ran towards the crane and saw a man inside. He wore a helmet and a vest."Hello, sir," Ben greeted. "Could you tell us how you make the crane move?"The man smiled and opened the door. He invited them to sit with him."Sure, I\'d be happy to," he said. "The crane has a motor and a cable. The motor raises and lowers the cable. The cable has a hook at the end. I control the hook with a joystick.""Impressive," Anna marveled. "You must be very intelligent to do that."The man chuckled and replied, "Thank you, but the crane is also intelligent. It has sensors and computers that help me. They tell me the weight limit and the reach limit. They also warn me of any danger or problem.""Really?" Ben asked.The man showed them a screen and some buttons. He explained how the sensors and computers worked. He also shared some rules and safety tips for operating the crane.Anna and Ben learned a lot from the man. They thanked him and bid farewell. They returned to their toys and pretended to be crane operators.They had fun and gained new knowledge. They discovered that the crane was not just a large toy, but a practical and intelligent machine. They also understood that the man was not just a driver, but a teacher and a friend. They became more curious, respectful, and grateful.', 1)
('Lily liked to do yoga with her mom. Yoga was when they made funny shapes with their bodies on a mat. Sometimes they were trees, sometimes they were cats, sometimes they were stars. Lily liked to stretch and breathe and feel calm.One day, Lily saw a big sack in the corner of the living room. She wondered what was inside. She asked her mom, but her mom said it was a surprise. Lily was curious. She wanted to see the surprise. She waited until her mom was busy in the kitchen, and then she tiptoed to the sack.She opened the sack and peeked inside. She saw lots of toys and books and clothes. They were all new and shiny and colorful. Lily was happy. She thought the sack was a gift for her. She pulled out a doll, a puzzle, a hat, and a ball. She played with them on the floor. She made a mess.Her mom came back and saw the mess. She was not happy. She said, "Lily, what have you done? This sack is not for you. It is for the children who don\'t have many things. We are going to give it to them tomorrow. You have to put everything back and make it tidy."Lily felt sad. She did not mean to be naughty. She said, "I\'m sorry, mom. I thought it was for me. I like the toys and books and clothes. Can I keep one?" Her mom said, "No, Lily. You have enough things. You have to share with others. That is what yoga teaches us. To be kind and generous and grateful. Now, help me put everything back and make it tidy."Lily helped her mom put everything back in the sack. She said goodbye to the doll, the puzzle, the hat, and the ball. She said, "I hope you make the children happy. Maybe they will do yoga with you." She hugged her mom and said, "I love you, mom. I\'m sorry I made a mess. Can we do yoga now?" Her mom said, "I love you too, Lily. Yes, we can do yoga now. Let\'s be trees." They smiled and made funny shapes with their bodies on the mat. They stretched and breathed and felt calm.', ' Past Tense:Lily liked to do yoga with her mom. We made funny shapes with our bodies on a mat. Sometimes we were trees, sometimes we were cats, sometimes we were stars. I liked to stretch and breathe and feel calm.One day, I saw a big sack in the corner of the living room. I wondered what was inside. I asked my mom, but she said it was a surprise. I was curious. I waited until she was busy in the kitchen, and then I tiptoed to the sack.I opened the sack and peeked inside. I saw lots of toys and books and clothes. They were all new and shiny and colorful. I was happy. I thought the sack was a gift for me. I pulled out a doll, a puzzle, a hat, and a ball. I played with them on the floor. I made a mess.My mom came back and saw the mess. She was not happy. She said, "Lily, what have you done? This sack was not for you. It is for the children who don\'t have many things. We were going to give it to them tomorrow. You have to put everything back and make it tidy."I felt sad. I did not mean to be naughty. I said, "I\'m sorry, mom. I thought it was for me. I like the toys and books and clothes. Can I keep one?" My mom said, "No, Lily. You have enough things. You have to share with others. That is what yoga teaches us. To be kind and generous and grateful. Now, help me put everything back and make it tidy."I helped my mom put everything back in the sack. I said goodbye to the doll, the puzzle, the hat, and the ball. I said, "I hope you make the children happy. Maybe they will do yoga with you." I hugged my mom and said, "I love you, mom. I\'m sorry I made a mess. Can we do yoga now?" My mom said, "I love you too, Lily. Yes, we can do yoga now. Let\'s be trees." We smiled and made funny shapes with our bodies on the mat. We stretched and breathed and felt calm.', 1)
('Lily was a tall girl who liked to eat toast for breakfast. She liked to put butter and jam on her toast and make it sweet and soft. She also liked to tell stories to her little brother, Ben, who was still in his crib.One morning, Lily woke up early and went to the kitchen. She saw a big loaf of bread on the counter and decided to make toast for herself and Ben. She took two slices of bread and put them in the toaster. She waited for them to pop up and then took them out. She put butter and jam on them and put them on a plate.She carried the plate to Ben\'s room and saw him sleeping. She smiled and said, "Wake up, Ben! I have toast for you!" She put the plate on his nightstand and climbed into his crib. She gave him a hug and a kiss and said, "Good morning, Ben! Do you want to hear a story?"Ben opened his eyes and saw Lily and the toast. He smiled and said, "Yes, please! I love your stories!" He took a bite of the toast and said, "Mmm, this is yummy! Thank you, Lily!"Lily said, "You\'re welcome, Ben! Now, listen to my story. It\'s about a tall princess who lived in a castle with a dragon. She was brave and smart and kind. Do you want to know what she did?"Ben nodded and said, "Yes, yes, tell me more!"Lily smiled and began to tell her story. She used her voice and her hands to make it fun and exciting. Ben listened and laughed and asked questions. They ate their toast and enjoyed their story. They were happy and loved each other very much.', ' Past Tense:Lily had been a tall girl who had liked to eat toast for her breakfast. She had enjoyed putting butter and jam on her toast, making it sweet and soft. She also had enjoyed telling stories to her little brother, Ben, who had still been in his crib.One morning, Lily had woken up early and had gone to the kitchen. She had seen a big loaf of bread on the counter and had decided to make toast for herself and Ben. She had taken two slices of bread and had put them in the toaster. She had waited for them to pop up and had then taken them out. She had put butter and jam on them and had put them on a plate.She had carried the plate to Ben\'s room and had seen him sleeping. She had smiled and had said, "Wake up, Ben! I had toast for you!" She had put the plate on his nightstand and had climbed into his crib. She had given him a hug and a kiss and had said, "Good morning, Ben! Do you want to hear a story?"Ben had opened his eyes and had seen Lily and the toast. He had smiled and had said, "Yes, please! I loved your stories!" He had taken a bite of the toast and had said, "Mmm, this was yummy! Thank you, Lily!"Lily had said, "You\'re welcome, Ben! Now, listen to my story. It had been about a tall princess who had lived in a castle with a dragon. She had been brave and smart and kind. Do you want to know what she had done?"Ben had nodded and had said, "Yes, yes, tell me more!"Lily had smiled and had begun to tell her story. She had used her voice and her hands to make it fun and exciting. Ben had listened and had laughed and had asked questions. They had eaten their toast and had enjoyed their story. They had been happy and had loved each other very much.', 1)
('Lily liked to design things with her crayons and paper. She made houses, flowers, animals and people. She was very good at drawing. One day, she wanted to design a figure of her best friend, Mia. She took a big paper and a blue crayon and started to draw."Look, Mommy, I am making Mia!" she said, showing her paper to her mom."That\'s very nice, Lily. You are a great artist," her mom said, smiling. "But don\'t forget to clean up your crayons when you are done."Lily nodded and went back to her drawing. She made Mia\'s hair, eyes, nose, mouth and dress. She was very happy with her figure. She wanted to show it to Mia the next day at school.But then, her little brother, Ben, came into her room. He saw the paper and the crayons. He liked to play with them. He did not know that Lily was designing something. He grabbed the paper and the crayons and ran away."Hey, give that back!" Lily shouted, chasing him. "That\'s mine!"Ben did not listen. He ran to the kitchen and hid behind the table. He thought it was a fun game. He took the crayons and scribbled all over the paper. He made lines, circles, dots and squiggles. He ruined Lily\'s figure.Lily followed him and saw what he did. She was very angry and sad. She cried and yelled at him."Ben, you are so bad! You ruined my figure of Mia! How could you do that? I worked so hard on it!"Ben did not understand why Lily was so upset. He thought he was just having fun. He did not say sorry. He just smiled and threw the paper on the floor.Lily picked up the paper and saw that her figure was hidden under the mess. She could not fix it. She could not show it to Mia. She felt like she lost her best friend. She ran to her mom and hugged her. She wished Ben was never born.', ' Past Tense:Lily enjoyed designing things with her crayons and paper. She made houses, flowers, animals, and people. She was excellent at drawing. One day, she decided to create a figure of her best friend, Mia. She took a large paper and a blue crayon and began to draw."Look, Mommy, I am making Mia!" she exclaimed, displaying her paper to her mom."That\'s very nice, Lily. You are a great artist," her mom replied, smiling. "But don\'t forget to clean up your crayons when you\'re done."Lily nodded and returned to her drawing. She made Mia\'s hair, eyes, nose, mouth, and dress. She was pleased with her figure. She wanted to show it to Mia the following day at school.However, her little brother, Ben, entered her room. He saw the paper and crayons and wanted to play. He didn\'t realize that Lily was creating something. He seized the paper and crayons and fled."Hey, give that back!" Lily shouted, pursuing him. "That\'s mine!"Ben disregarded her. He went to the kitchen and concealed himself behind the table. He believed it was a fun game. He took the crayons and scribbled all over the paper. He made lines, circles, dots, and squiggles. He destroyed Lily\'s figure.Lily arrived and saw what he had done. She was enraged and disheartened. She cried and scolded him."Ben, you were so naughty! You ruined my figure of Mia! How could you do that? I had put so much effort into it!"Ben didn\'t grasp why Lily was so upset. He thought he was merely having fun. He didn\'t apologize. He just grinned and tossed the paper on the floor.Lily retrieved the paper and discovered that her figure was concealed beneath the chaos. She couldn\'t restore it. She couldn\'t present it to Mia. She felt as if she had lost her best friend. She ran to her mom and embraced her. She wished Ben had never been born.', 1)
('Ben and Mia are twins. They like to play with their toy cars. They have many cars of different colors and sizes. They drive them on the floor, on the sofa, on the table. They make noises like vroom, beep, honk.One day, they find a big black car in the garage. It is their dad\'s car. It looks shiny and cool. They want to play with it. They open the door and climb inside. They see many buttons and levers. They touch them and pull them. The car makes noises like click, whirr, ding."Look, Mia, I can drive!" Ben says. He turns the key in the ignition. The car starts to move. It goes forward and backward. It bumps into the wall and the shelves. It makes noises like crash, bang, screech."Stop, Ben, stop!" Mia says. She is scared. She wants to get out. But the door is locked. She cries and screams. She pushes the horn. It makes a loud noise like honk, honk, honk.Dad hears the noise. He runs to the garage. He sees the car moving and shaking. He sees Ben and Mia inside. He is angry and worried. He opens the door and takes them out. He hugs them and checks if they are hurt. He is glad they are okay. He scolds them and tells them to never play with his car again. He says it is dangerous and not a toy. He says they could have broken the car or hurt themselves or others.Ben and Mia are sorry. They say they are sorry to dad and to the car. They promise to never do it again. They learn that they should not touch things that are not theirs. They learn that they should listen to dad and be careful. They learn that driving is not a game. They go back to their toy cars. They drive them safely and happily. They make noises like vroom, beep, honk.', ' Past Tense:Ben and Mia were twins who enjoyed playing with their toy cars. They had numerous cars of various colors and sizes. They drove their cars on the floor, the sofa, and the table. They made noises such as "vroom," "beep," and "honk."One day, they discovered a large black car in the garage. It was their father\'s car, which looked shiny and cool to them. Eager to play with it, they opened the door and climbed inside. They were fascinated by the numerous buttons and levers they found. They touched and pulled them, and the car made sounds like "click," "whirr," and "ding.""Look, Mia, I can drive!" Ben exclaimed. He turned the key in the ignition, and the car began to move. It went forward and backward, bumping into the wall and shelves. The car made noises like "crash," "bang," and "screech.""Stop, Ben, stop!" Mia cried out, frightened. She wanted to exit the car but couldn\'t as the door was locked. She began to cry and scream, pushing the horn to make a loud noise, "honk, honk, honk."Dad was alerted by the noise and rushed to the garage. He saw the car moving and shaking, with Ben and Mia inside. Angered and worried, he opened the door and took them out, hugging them and checking for injuries. He scolded them and told them never to play with his car again, explaining that it was dangerous and not a toy. They could have broken the car or hurt themselves or others.Ben and Mia apologized to their father and the car. They promised never to touch it again and learned valuable lessons about respecting others\' belongings, listening to their parents, and understanding the difference between play and danger. They returned to their toy cars and drove them safely and happily, making noises like "vroom," "beep," and "honk."', 1)
('Anna and Ben were at the park with their mom. They liked to play on the swings, the slide and the sandbox. They saw many other kids and some dogs too. They waved to their friends and said hello."Mom, can we have ice-cream?" Anna asked. She loved ice-cream, especially chocolate and vanilla. Ben nodded. He liked ice-cream too, but he preferred strawberry and banana."Sure, sweeties. Let\'s go to the ice-cream truck," mom said. She took their hands and walked with them to the truck. There were many flavors and colors of ice-cream. Anna and Ben chose their favorites and mom paid the man."Thank you, mom!" Anna and Ben said. They licked their ice-creams and smiled. They were very yummy and cold.As they were eating their ice-creams, they saw a little girl with a big hat and a pink dress. She was holding a balloon and a teddy bear. She looked very adorable. She waved to Anna and Ben and came closer."Hi, I\'m Lily. Do you want to play with me?" she asked. She had a friendly voice and a cute smile."Hi, I\'m Anna and this is Ben. We would love to play with you," Anna said. She liked Lily\'s hat and balloon. Ben liked her teddy bear."Great! Let\'s go to the sandbox. I have some toys there," Lily said. She led them to the sandbox and they started to make sandcastles, bridges and tunnels. They had a lot of fun and shared their toys and ice-creams.Anna, Ben and Lily became good friends. They played until it was time to go home. They hugged and waved goodbye. They promised to see each other again soon. They were very happy.', ' Past Tense:Anna and Ben had been at the park with their mom. They had enjoyed playing on the swings, the slide, and the sandbox. ('Lila and Tom were best friends. They liked to play in the park with their toys. One day, they saw some big kids coming. The big kids looked mean and angry. They wanted to take Lila and Tom\'s toys."Give us your toys, or we will hurt you!" one of the big kids shouted.Lila and Tom were scared. They did not want to lose their toys. They did not want to get hurt. They hugged each other and held their toys tight."No, these are our toys! Go away!" Tom said.The big kids laughed. They moved closer to Lila and Tom. They reached out their hands to grab the toys."Stop! Leave them alone!" a voice said.Lila and Tom looked up. They saw Sam, their older brother. Sam was strong and brave. He came to the park to protect them. He stood in front of Lila and Tom and faced the big kids."These are my sister and brother. You cannot take their toys. You cannot hurt them. Go away, or I will make you go away!" Sam said.The big kids did not laugh anymore. They saw that Sam was stronger than them. They did not want to fight him. They did not want to start a war. They turned around and ran away.Lila and Tom were happy. They thanked Sam for saving them. They gave him a hug and a kiss."You are the best brother ever!" Lila said."You are our hero!" Tom said.Sam smiled. He hugged them back. He was glad he could protect them."Let\'s go home and have some cookies," Sam said.Lila and Tom nodded. They picked up their toys and followed Sam. They felt safe and loved. They were a happy family.', ' Past Tense:Lila and Tom were best friends. They had enjoyed playing in the park with their toys. One day, they spotted some older, menacing children approaching. The children appeared angry and determined to take Lila and Tom\'s toys."Give us your toys, or we will hurt you!" one of the children barked.Lila and Tom were frightened. They didn\'t want to lose their cherished possessions or get injured. They clung to each other and their toys protectively."No, these are our toys! Go away!" Tom asserted.The children laughed derisively. They advanced towards Lila and Tom, reaching out to seize their toys."Stop! Leave them alone!" a voice rang out.Lila and Tom looked up in relief. Their older brother, Sam, had arrived at the park to shield them. He stood between them and the children, facing the intruders bravely."These are my sister and brother. You cannot take their toys. You cannot harm them. Go away, or I will make you leave!" Sam declared.The children no longer mocked them. They recognized Sam\'s strength and decided against engaging in a confrontation. They retreated, leaving Lila, Tom, and Sam unharmed.Lila and Tom were grateful. They thanked Sam for his intervention. They embraced him, expressing their appreciation."You are the best brother ever!" Lila exclaimed."You are our hero!" Tom agreed.Sam beamed with pride. He returned their affectionate gestures. "Let\'s go home and have some cookies," he suggested.Lila and Tom agreed. They gathered their toys and followed Sam home, feeling secure and cherished. They were a contented family.', 1)
('Tom and Mia are friends. They like to play with equipment in the park. They have a slide, a swing, a seesaw and a climbing frame. They test the equipment every day. ('Tom and Lily were playing in the park. They liked to slide, swing and run. But they did not like the big tree. The big tree had a hole in its trunk. It looked like a mouth. Tom and Lily thought the big tree was scary.One day, Tom had an idea. He wanted to scare Lily. He said, "Lily, let\'s play hide and seek. You count to ten and I hide." Lily agreed. She closed her eyes and counted. Tom ran to the big tree. He climbed inside the hole. He thought, "This will be fun. Lily will be so scared when I jump out."Lily finished counting. She opened her eyes and looked for Tom. She saw his shoes sticking out of the hole. She smiled. She knew where he was. She tiptoed to the big tree. She said, "I found you, Tom. You are in the big tree." She reached for his shoes. But then, something happened.Tom heard a loud noise. He felt something move in the hole. He looked up. He saw a big, furry head. It had sharp teeth and yellow eyes. It was a raccoon. The raccoon was angry. It did not like Tom in its home. It growled and hissed. Tom was terrified. He screamed and ran out of the hole.Lily saw Tom run out of the hole. She saw the raccoon chase him. She was shocked. She did not know there was a raccoon in the big tree. She said, "Tom, watch out! There is a raccoon!" She ran after him. They both ran to the other side of the park. They did not stop until they were safe.Tom and Lily hugged each other. They were glad they were okay. They looked at the big tree. They did not like it anymore. They said, "Let\'s never play near the big tree again. It is too scary." They decided to play somewhere else. They found a sandbox. They thought it was fun. They forgot about the big tree and the raccoon. They did not try to scare each other again. They learned their lesson.', ' Past Tense:Tom and Lily played in the park. They enjoyed sliding, swinging, and running. However, they disliked the big tree. The big tree had a hole in its trunk, which resembled a mouth, making it appear scary to Tom and Lily.One day, Tom devised a plan to scare Lily. He suggested, "Let\'s play hide and seek, Lily. You count to ten, and I\'ll hide." Lily consented. She closed her eyes and counted. Tom sprinted towards the big tree, climbed inside the hole, and waited, anticipating Lily\'s fear.Lily finished counting and opened her eyes. She searched for Tom. She spotted his shoes protruding from the hole. She chuckled, knowing Tom\'s hiding spot. However, an unexpected event occurred.Tom heard a loud noise and felt something moving in the hole. He peered up and saw a large, furry head with sharp teeth and yellow eyes. It was a raccoon, protective of its home. The raccoon growled and hissed, terrifying Tom. He screamed and fled from the hole.Lily witnessed Tom\'s hasty exit and the enraged raccoon chasing him. She was startled, unaware of the raccoon\'s presence in the big tree. She shouted, "Tom, watch out! There\'s a raccoon!" She pursued Tom, both of them fleeing to the other side of the park for safety.Tom and Lily embraced each other, relieved to be unharmed. They no longer admired the big tree. They declared, "Let\'s never play near the big tree again. It\'s too scary," and opted to play in a sandbox instead. They abandoned their plans to scare each other and learned their lesson.', 1)
('Sara and Ben are friends. They like to play with cards. They have many cards with animals and colors. They make piles and match the cards.One day, Sara finds a card that is torn. It is a card with a big lion. She likes the lion card. She is sad. She shows the card to Ben."Oh no, your card is broken!" Ben says. "Do you want to fix it?""Yes, please. How can we fix it?" ('Lily liked to write with her crayons. She wrote her name, her mom\'s name, and her dog\'s name on many papers. She also liked to draw flowers and stars and hearts. She was very proud of her writing and drawing.One day, she saw a big white wall in the living room. She thought it was a good place to write and draw. She took her crayons and started to write and draw on the wall. She wrote "Lily loves Mom" and drew a big heart. She smiled and felt happy.But then, her mom came into the living room and saw the wall. She was very angry. She shouted at Lily and said, "Lily, what did you do? You made a big mess on the wall! You are a bad girl! You have to clean it up right now!"Lily felt scared and sad. She did not mean to make her mom angry. She wanted to make her mom happy. She said, "Mom, I\'m sorry. I wanted to write and draw for you. I love you, Mom."Her mom did not listen. She took Lily\'s crayons and threw them in the trash. She gave Lily a sponge and a bucket of water and said, "You have to scrub the wall until it is clean. And no more writing and drawing on the wall, ever!"Lily started to cry. She did not want to scrub the wall. She wanted her crayons back. She wanted her mom to hug her and say, "It\'s okay, Lily. I love you, too." She wanted her mom to give her a gentle massage on her back and make her feel better. But her mom did not do that. She just walked away and left Lily alone with the wall. Lily felt very unhappy. She wished she never wrote and drew on the wall. She wished she had a different mom.', ' Past Tense:Lily enjoyed writing with her crayons. You\'re a bad girl! You need to clean it up right away!"Lily felt frightened and sad. She hadn\'t intended to upset her mom. She wanted to make her mom happy. She apologized, "Mom, I\'m sorry. I wrote and drew for you. I love you, Mom."Her mom disregarded her. She took Lily\'s crayons and discarded them in the trash. ("Once upon a time, there was a kangaroo named Joey. Joey was a big kangaroo who liked to hop and play all day. One day, Joey got lost in the forest and he was confused. He didn't know which way to go to find his way back home.Joey sat down and started to plan. He thought about the way he came and tried to remember the trees and bushes he saw. After a while, Joey figured out the right way and started to hop towards home. When Joey finally made it back home, all his kangaroo friends were so happy to see him. They asked him where he had been and Joey explained that he got lost but he made a plan to find his way back. From that day on, Joey was known as the smartest kangaroo in the forest.", " Once upon a time, there was a kangaroo named Joey. Joey had been a big kangaroo, known for his love of hopping and play. One day, Joey grew confused when he got lost in the forest. He sat down, trying to recall the way home. Memories of the trees and bushes along his previous path flooded his mind. After some time, Joey identified the correct direction and began to hop towards home. Upon his return, his kangaroo friends welcomed him warmly. They inquired about his whereabouts and Joey shared his tale of getting lost but devising a plan to find his way back. From that day forward, Joey was revered as the forest's smartest kangaroo.", 1)
